general: This law makes sure that video recordings, like movies or TV shows, are not pirated or copied without permission. It also helps people who want to make their own videos at home by making sure they can use their cameras and other equipment legally. The law repeals and revives old rules from 1984 so that they match up with modern technology better. This way, everyone can enjoy watching videos safely and legally!

series.short: "Repeal of Video Recordings Act 1984 and New Technical Standards Procedure"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Video Recordings Act 1984 is repealed and its provisions are revived, effective on the date the act is passed.
* Simplified point 2: The Technical Standards Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 June 1998 lays down a procedure for providing information in the field of technical standards and regulations.
* Simplified point 3: Transitional provisions are included in the Schedule of the Act.
* Simplified point 4: The Act extends to England and Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland.

summary:
The Video Recordings Act 2010 is a law that updates and replaces the old Video Recordings Act 1984. This new law makes sure that video recordings, like DVDs and streaming services, meet certain standards and provide information about them. It also includes rules for how these recordings can be used and sold. The law applies to all parts of the United Kingdom (England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland).
This law is important because it helps make sure that video recordings are safe and reliable for consumers to use. It also helps ensure that companies that sell or rent out video recordings follow certain rules and provide accurate information about their products.
Overall, the Video Recordings Act 2010 is a law that protects consumers and ensures fair business practices when it comes to video recordings.
single:
* The Video Recordings Act 2010 repeals and revives provisions of the Video Recordings Act 1984.
* The repealed provisions include sections 1 to 17, 19, 21, and 22 of the 1984 Act.
* The revived provisions come into force again on the day the Act is passed.
* The Act extends to England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland.
* The Schedule to the Act contains transitional provisions.
IN PLAIN ENGLISH:
The Video Recordings Act 2010 repeals and revives parts of the Video Recordings Act 1984. The repealed parts include rules about the distribution of video recordings. These rules will come back into force on the day the Act is passed. The Act applies to England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. The Act also includes transitional provisions to help with the transition to the new rules.
